author: abc
post_text: April 10, 2017 at 12:25 PM#1HelloI would like to create a macro that will create a macro lineIt is quite easy to do, but I can not integrate the quotation marks in the right placeStore macro 1.1Store macro 1.1.1Assign Macro 1.1.1 / cmd = "Group 2 At Preset 2." Blind Up ""I need quotation marks on each side of "Blind Up", to call the preset, because there is a space between the two wordsBut since there are 4 quotation marks, the GrandMa does not includeIf you have an idea of the correct syntax, it will be greatThank you in advance

posts.author: abc
posts.post_text: April 10, 2017 at 12:25 PM#1HelloI would like to create a macro that will create a macro lineIt is quite easy to do, but I can not integrate the quotation marks in the right placeStore macro 1.1Store macro 1.1.1Assign Macro 1.1.1 / cmd = "Group 2 At Preset 2." Blind Up ""I need quotation marks on each side of "Blind Up", to call the preset, because there is a space between the two wordsBut since there are 4 quotation marks, the GrandMa does not includeIf you have an idea of the correct syntax, it will be greatThank you in advance

posts.author: glad
posts.post_text: April 10, 2017 at 1:47 PM#2to my knowledge this is not possible....

posts.author: abc
posts.post_text: April 10, 2017 at 3:19 PM#3Thanks Glad for your answerThis allowed me to stop looking in this directionSo I use the variables of the consoleStore macro 1.1Store macro 1.1.1Setuservar $Pos1 = ' "Blind Up" 'Assign Macro 1.1.1 / cmd = "Group 2 At Preset 2. $Pos1"Thank youHave a good day

posts.post_text: April 12, 2017 at 5:59 PM#4HiJust avoid space in names. Use Blind_up for exemple.

posts.post_text: May 26, 2017 at 6:37 PM#5I don't know if that will help but... You can put quotes in a var by putting them inside it, for example:Code$"YourVar"

title: The correct syntax with multiple quotation marks "..."
